<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of fast_simple_hash:
```c
static uint32_t
fast_simple_hash (const uint8_t *data,
                  size_t data_size)
{
  uint32_t hash;

  if (0 != data_size)
  {
    size_t i;
    hash = data[0];
    for (i = 1; i < data_size; i++)
      hash = _MHD_ROTL32 (hash, 7) ^ data[i];
  }
  else
    hash = 0;

  return hash;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function fast_simple_hash:
#define _MHD_ROTL32(value32, bits) ((uint32_t)__builtin_rotateleft32((value32),(bits)))
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: for (i = 1; i < data_size; i++) hash = _MHD_ROTL32 (hash, 7) ^ data[i];
explanation: Only the for-loop and items that affect the for-loop clauses need investigation for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2. The listed fragments cover the loop header (initialization, condition, iteration expression), the loop counter declaration, the loop body expression, and the macro invoked inside the loop body (functions called within the loop body are part of the loop behaviour). Other parts of the function do not influence whether the for loop is well-formed under Rule 14.2: the function signature, the declaration and initialization of 'hash' outside the loop, the surrounding if/else that guards the loop, the else branch 'hash = 0;', and the return statement do not participate in the for-loop clauses, do not modify the loop counter, nor are they called from within the loop body, so they do not need to be investigated for this specific rule.
